method_summary: The ID-GNN introduces a class of message passing Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) that extends existing architectures by considering nodes' identities during message passing. This approach allows ID-GNNs to generate distinct embeddings for nodes residing in similar neighborhood structures, addressing limitations in traditional GNNs constrained by the 1-Weisfeiler-Lehman (1-WL) graph isomorphism test. ID-GNN employs an inductive identity coloring technique to differentiate the identity node from its neighbors, leading to enhanced expressive power. The method can be implemented in two ways: a general version that applies heterogeneous message passing and a simplified version that injects identity information using augmented node features.
experiment_summary: ID-GNN was evaluated across multiple datasets and tasks, showing significant improvements, such as a 40% accuracy increase on challenging node, edge, and graph property prediction tasks compared to existing GNNs. ID-GNN demonstrated a 15% improvement in ROCAUC for real-world link prediction tasks and maintained or surpassed performance over other task-specific graph networks across multiple benchmarks. The experiments confirmed the versatility and efficacy of ID-GNN in overcoming previously identified limitations of GNNs.
